citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The 8-year-old neutered male wolf hybrid “Walter” is not receiving Gabapentin for his fully torn ACL injury as directed by
the attending veterinarian. “Walter” has a significant limp on his left rear limb observed during inspection. Medical records
show that the attending veterinarian directed the facility to ensure that he is ‘staying on Flexira and Gabapentin for the
pain’. The facility representative stated that Walter was not currently receiving any medication for the injury due to inability
to tolerate the side effects of the Flexira. The attending veterinarian verified that she was aware that the facility has
stopped giving the Flexira as prescribed. However, she verified that the facility had not communicated that the facility was
not giving the gabapentin as directed. Failure to let the attending veterinarian know that changes have been made to the
medications could result in unnecessary pain and suffering for the animal. The mechanism of direct and frequent
communication is required so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being
is conveyed to the attending veterinarian. To be corrected by March 16, 2025.

The facility failed to maintain housing facilities free of sharp points that might injure the animals. In the wolf hybrid
enclosure, there is a portion of fencing where the chicken wire has metal points turned into the wolf hybrid area. Failure to
maintain housing facilities in good repair can lead to injury of the animals contained in them. The licensee must maintain
housing facilities so they are free of sharp points that might cause injury to the animal. To be corrected by March 16th
2025.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The food and water receptacles in the wolf hybrid enclosure are not being sanitized. While observing the keeper feed and
water the wolf hybrids, she was asked about their cleaning process for receptacles. She stated that the food and water
bowls are not sanitized. The water buckets are emptied and then filled with clean water. The food bowls are filled with
water, scrubbed with a stainless-steel scouring sponge, rinsed with water and emptied, then placed upside down on top of
the box enclosure to dry. Failure to sanitize the receptacles could contaminate the food and water leading to decreased
appetite and potential illness. To fix this problem, the licensee should sanitize the food and water receptacles at least
once every 2 weeks to prevent an accumulation of dirt, debris, food waste, excreta, and other disease hazards. To be
corrected by March 16, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
